item.title: session and cookie in express
item.description:
Cookie

Use cookie-parser middleware to parse the cookie header in a request.

Use req.cookies to get the parsed result.

To set cookie:

All this method does is set the response header property Set-Cookie. The options can be :

  • httpOnly: Boolean (accessed only by web server )
  • expires: Date
  • maxAge: int (millseconds)
  • secure: Boolean (https use only)
  • path: String (path for the value)
  • domain: String
  • encode: Function
  • signed: Boolean

Session

Use express-session middleware to do session management. The default store is in-memory storage just for debug and development.

This middleware take usage of cookie, it set a default cookie named connect.sid with a value of the session id in client cookie, and store the information in server side. Every request, client send with request header Cookie with the connect.sid, and the session middelware checks it with in-memory storage, and use the private information stored in the session to configure next response.

Usage

Take the login and logout as example. A user make a request to the login page, and enter his/her credential, then commit to make a post to same page. The server checks the data from database and send message back to the client. If credential is correct, Then client script do the redirect action, else show the error message. If log out action is triggered, the client set the relative cookie value to null. Since the server side only use cookie to identify user, the user will be logged out.

item.title: session and cookie in stateless http
item.description:
The http is a stateless protocol, which means that the requests does not recognize between each other and every request is new for the server. So to make a stateful application, we must adopt some mechanism to make the server know which client the request comes from. If you make a GET request with correct credentials to the server, then the server will make a response with headers contains such items:

Then the client( your browser ) will set cookies on your device. Check the cookie in your browser on that site, you can see that cookie now contain the key-value has the infomation in just the response header.

After logged in successfully, every request will contain header infomation :

When you want to log out the site, the client will make a POST request to the server, commonly will be an address like https://example.com/logout, and the server will make a response with header contains also cookie info:

Then the client will erase the coresponding key in the cookie. And often the server will also send a redirect information, that is the Location header, then the client will goto that address, normally will be the homepage.

As we can see, the statefulness is achieved by add session information in the request and response headers. At client side, the infos are stored in cookies, and will be persistly on. At server side, the infos are stored either in memory or in a database.

If you manually delete the cookies, you will be logged out.

## Above is the situation in brower environment, and the cookie set by Set-Cookie can not get directly by the user or customized script. The work are done by the client at deep. If you are making a mobile app with the net communication capability, you can set the customized property in the request header and response header, and store the token in some safe place on your mobile device (such as the key-chain in iOS).

Security issue

Since the state if only relied on the session-id, which means if one has the session-id and make a request with this information, he/she can automatically log in as the user while not need the username and password.

item.title: a simple Read, Send, and Receive server in nodejs
item.description:
Use the readline and dgram to write a simple chat server.

This will listen on a port and send message to another port, you can test this on one computer. If you want to communicate between different computer, you need use broadcast and change code to:

Send message to ip address 192.168.1.255 will broadcast message to all the devices with ip address 192.168.1.*. Setting all the bits of an IP address to one, or 255.255.255.255, forms the limited broadcast address. Sending a UDP datagram to this address delivers the message to any host on the local network segment. Because routers never forward messages sent to this address, only hosts on the network segment receive the broadcast message.

Broadcasts can be directed to specific portions of a network by setting all bits of the host identifier. For example, to send a broadcast to all hosts on the network identified by IP addresses starting with 192.168.1, use the address 192.168.1.255.
